title.narrative: Humanitarian aid to crisis-affected communities in CAR

description.narrative: Dutch Relief Alliance Joint Response Central African Republic Phase 4 LWF

This program contributes to building stronger and more resilient communities through the reduction of food insecurity of families and malnutrition among school-attending children, improving access to water and latrines, as well as enhancing social cohesion in Ouham & Ouham Pendé provinces.

Through this project ACT Alliance member Lutheran World Federation (LWF) will support crisis-affected communities in Central African Republic (CAR) through an integrated program including Food security, Wash, and Protection activities. The program activities will be implemented in 2 priority areas: Ouham & Ouham-Pende provinces.
The activities will include: - Food Security: school feeding, establishment of school and community gardens, distribution of tools & seeds, agricultural training, - Protection: train youth as peace ambassadors, organize awareness raising on peaceful co-existence, radio broadcasts, - Wash: construction of boreholes/water sources, latrine construction, and training of water management committees.
The children in schools are the first entry point for implementation of the program, and from there involving the whole community through community-based approaches. The program contributes to building stronger and more resilient communities through the reduction of food insecurity and malnutrition in school-attending children, improving access to water and latrines, as well as enhancing social cohesion in Ouham and Ouham Pendé provinces.
Short background: Central African Republic (CAR) suffers from a complex crisis. The crisis started in December 2012 when fighting broke out between armed factions leading to overthrowing of the government in May 2013. Currently, after more than five years of conflict, an estimated 2,7 million people or more than half of the population are in need of humanitarian assistance.
This program is funded by a contribution from Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance (DRA), as well as by a contribution from our own Kerk in Actie funds.
In this humanitarian response in the Central African Republic ICCO&Kerk in Actie collaborate with ACT Alliance member Lutheran World Federation.
From Bozoum activities in Ouham Pende are implemented
LWF implements activities in collaboration with SOS &#38; PLAN in Ouham (Bossangoa and Bouca
Headoffice / country office of LWF is located in Bangui, capital of CAR

title.narrative: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets

comment.narrative: FSC-R1: Vegetable production for most vulnerable HHs, though parcellation, clearing & fencing of 5Ha of land and creation of 20 wells for irrigation (all through CFW), distribution of seeds, gardening tools and provision of training on vegetable/crop
11/7/18: This activity will start in September, since the dry season is a better period to implement this

FSC-R1: Vegetable production for most vulnerable HHs, though parcellation, clearing & fencing of 5Ha of land and creation of 20 wells for irrigation (all through CFW), distribution of seeds, gardening tools and provision of training on vegetable/crop
AS of 31/12/18: activity completed - training done & vegetables produced

FSC-R1: Vegetable production for most vulnerable HHs, though parcellation, clearing & fencing of 5Ha of land and creation of 20 wells for irrigation (all through CFW), distribution of seeds, gardening tools and provision of training on vegetable/crop
AS of 31/12/18: activity completed - training done & vegetables produced

FSC-R1: Vegetable production for most vulnerable HHs, though parcellation, clearing & fencing of 5Ha of land and creation of 20 wells for irrigation (all through CFW), distribution of seeds, gardening tools and provision of training on vegetable/crop

As of 31/8/18: Beneficiaries have been selected, lobby for access to land done. The training for the 70 heads of HH (23 Female, 47 male) on vegetable production and seed multiplication will be done during first 2 weeks of Sept.

title.narrative: Number of people provided with cash for work transfers

comment.narrative: SCH-R2: Number of people benefiting from CFW for parcellation, clearing land, installation/rehab wells, compost site construction of vegetable & rain-fed agriculture activities
1203 people from 223 HHs benefited from CFW participating in activities of parcellation, clearing land, installation/rehab wells, compost site construction.
SCH-R2: Number of people benefiting from CFW for parcellation, clearing land, installation/rehab wells, compost site construction of vegetable & rain-fed agriculture activities
As of 31/12/18: More beneficiaries than planned because of the project planned to orient the activities to those are not direct beneficiaries of farmers activities.
SCH-R2: Number of people benefiting from CFW for parcellation, clearing land, installation/rehab wells, compost site construction of vegetable & rain-fed agriculture activities
Cash for work given to people who worked on preparation of agricultural land for community gardening

title.narrative: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

comment.narrative: WSH-R4: Construction and rehabilitation of 15 water points including training & equipping water management committees
13 water points have been realized; 2 remaining are in process
WSH-R4: Construction and rehabilitation of 15 water points including training & equipping water management committees
Preparatory work on logistics and quotations have been done; implementation to follow in due course
WSH-R4: Construction and rehabilitation of 15 water points including training & equipping water management committees
Three (3) new boreholes have been constructed & 22 water points have been rehabilitated. So an increase in number.

title.narrative: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs

comment.narrative: FSC-R2: Schoolfeeding program that will use part of the harvest of vegetable and rain-fed agriculture
As of 31/8/18: This activity uses the yields of the two activities above, and this will evaluate when the harvest are done and when the schools have started.
FSC-R2: Schoolfeeding program that will use part of the harvest of vegetable and rain-fed agriculture

Children of the targeted HHs are counted here in the end. The planned number of children were taken with the assumption of reaching many children in the schools with some level of school feeding, which used the inputs from the vegetable gardens for school meals. In practice this was a bridge too far seeing the limited time of the project. Some school interventions took place, but we do not deem it fair to calculate theto be beneficiaries taking all school children.
FSC-R2: Schoolfeeding program that will use part of the harvest of vegetable and rain-fed agriculture
This will follow after the community gardens produce

title.narrative: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets

comment.narrative: FSC-R1: Rain Fed agriculture production for most vulnerable HHs, though parcellation, clearing & fencing of 50Ha of land (though CFW), distribution of seeds and gardening tools, provision of training, organisation of exchange visits of farmer groups

Through CFW community gardens have been prepared though parcellation, clearing & fencing of 50Ha of land (though CFW). 200 most vulnerable HHs have received seeds and gardening tools.

title.narrative: PRO-R6: Capacity building (Protection) - social cohesion & GBV

comment.narrative: -Youth engagement on social cohesion trhough training and follow-up of 20 youth ambassadors -Organize trainings on GBV for community leaders, APE, AME, teachers and community leaders
20 youth ambassadors trained. Other training: materials ready, and training planned for in July
-Youth engagement on social cohesion trhough training and follow-up of 20 youth ambassadors -Organize trainings on GBV for community leaders, APE, AME, teachers and community leaders
As of 31/12/18: the planned figure was an overestimation (omittedly included the Wash committees)
-Youth engagement on social cohesion trhough training and follow-up of 20 youth ambassadors -Organize trainings on GBV for community leaders, APE, AME, teachers and community leaders
The remaining number of beneficiaries will be trained when the schools start in Sept/Oct

title.narrative: PRO-R5: Protection information dissemination (GBV & social cohesion)

comment.narrative: -Awareness raising on GBV -Organize awareness sessions on social cohesion, including organising cultural and social activities (sports / dance / culinary / traditional games)

As of 31/12/18: Different activities resulted in this total number of people reached: 1. sensitization activities to 4414 people, 2. training of PTAs&students (1638), 3. cultural caravans (5318 people)
-Awareness raising on GBV -Organize awareness sessions on social cohesion, including organising cultural and social activities (sports / dance / culinary / traditional games)
Awareness raising activities and cultural events have taken place; a campaign (caravan) planned for later in July
-Awareness raising on GBV -Organize awareness sessions on social cohesion, including organising cultural and social activities (sports / dance / culinary / traditional games)
Cultural and social events have been organized

title.narrative: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

comment.narrative: WSH-R2: Construction of 39 latrine blocks (3 blocks per school) and training of the WASH committee
53 latrines have been constructed in the targeted schools; less pupils in schools than expected
WSH-R2: Construction of 39 latrine blocks (3 blocks per school) and training of the WASH committee
A challenge emerged with the constructor which has now been sorted, and construction is now expected to start soon

title.narrative: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, montoring and/or evaluation of the programme

comment.narrative: ACC-R1: -Involvement of community leaders, members of AMEs/APEs, teachers and youth ambassadors -Involvement of Wash committee members
11/7/18 no specific data filled in for this yet, but involvement clearly is there through committees and consultations
ACC-R1: -Involvement of community leaders, members of AMEs/APEs, teachers and youth ambassadors -Involvement of Wash committee members
180 PTA members for protection/social cohesion activities and 91 (13x7) Wash committee members so far
ACC-R1: -Involvement of community leaders, members of AMEs/APEs, teachers and youth ambassadors -Involvement of Wash committee members

The planning figure was an overestimation of beneficiaries. In total 100 people (community leaders, teachers, members of the Association of Parents of Pupils (APE), women members of mothers' associations (AME)) have been trained on child protection and the prevention of (GBV). Furthermore 80 women members of the mothers' associations (AME) have been trained on leadership, gender-based violence (GBV) and counseling. And 105 Wash committee members
